Award.AwardTitle: WORKSHOP: Ethics in Experimental Political Science- May 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Summary

Awareness of ethical issues in experimental political science is growing. This workshop brings together political science scholars and research integrity scholars to address critical needs in the ethical design, review, and implementation of experimental research. Unlike past discussions within political science, this workshop includes both political scientists engaged in experimental research and experts in the ethics of human-subjects research to develop best practice recommendations that will protect human subjects, researchers, the field of political science, institutions of higher learning, and the public's investment in science.

Technical Summary

Awareness of ethical issues in experimental political science is growing. This workshop brings together political science scholars and research integrity scholars to address critical needs in the ethical design, review, and implementation of experimental research. Unlike past discussions within political science, this workshop includes both political scientists engaged in experimental research and experts in the ethics of human-subjects research. Invited speakers and discussants will address in both panel and round table form the following issue areas: (1) special issues in consent and deceptive research; (2) managing incidental findings and collateral and community harms; (3) working with community and industry partners to conduct responsible research; (4) enhancing community capacity for review and consent in internationally sponsored research; (5) identifying descriptive and normative baselines when assessing risk, harm, and exploitation; (6) quantifying psychological harms; and (7) special concerns when using pre-existing data sets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On May 17-18, 2016, Dr. Trisha Phillips conducted a two-day workshop focused on ethics and experimental political science in Morgantown, West Virginia.

 

The workshop was inspired by the growing concern, among political scientists and the public, about certain field experiments and research interventions. These experiments included troubling issues of deception, third party harms, illegal activities, and impact on elections and other political processes. In many cases, these issues pointed to larger problems in accountability. The goal of the workshop was to invite scholars from other fields with a specialization in research ethics into this conversation, so that the treatment of similar issues in other disciplines could inform the response to problems raised by experimental political science. Essentially, the goal of the workshop was to break down the disciplinary "silos" that typically obstruct the sharing of specialized knowledge and experience across programmatic boundaries.

 

The workshop was successful in bringing together a multi-disciplinary group of scholars to discuss best practices in the design, review, implementation, and dissemination of experimental research in political science. Participants included 37 experts representing a variety of career stages and a broad range of disciplinary backgrounds and research expertise including in philosophy, religious studies, public policy, public administration, political science, bioethics, behavioral medicine, sociology, genetics, and social psychology. Many of the workshop participants held leadership positions in their field.

 

The event began with a welcome dinner on May 16 (co-sponsored by John D. Rockefeller IV School of Policy and Politics, the Department of Political Science, and Office of Research Integrity and Compliance at West Virginia University); followed by working sessions on May 17 and May 18. These sessions consisted of invited presentations on the state of the field; organizational ethics; prospective peer review; deception; randomized controlled field experiments; interventions and manipulations; publishing ethics; authorship; accountability; and the scope of research protections. Each presentation was followed by lively and productive discussions. The working meals were devoted to small group discussions on focused topics and large group discussions on "next steps".

 

The workshop facilitated a productive transdisciplinary discussion that will likely have an impact on participants, other political scientists, and the direction of the field. All of the participants benefited from the discussions in ways that will continue to influence their work.  Additionally, two participants benefited from the multi-disciplinary networking and dialogue and are now co-editing a multi-disciplinary Oxford Handbook to Research Ethics; several other participants benefitted from the multi-disciplinary feedback and have now published their work in various forums. Two participants presented the workshop findings to IRB professionals through a PRIM&R webinar, which will likely improve both the experience and quality of the IRB review process for political science researchers. Four participants were subsequently appointed to the American Political Science Association's ad hoc Committee on Humans Subjects Research and charged with rewriting the association's code of ethics as it pertains to human subjects research. This will likely impact many political scientists and the direction of the field. Reports from the workshop have been disseminated in conference and invited presentations, and other workshop products are in development.
